pullRequest.title: [1.16.x] Add loot table ID in Global Loot Modifiers
pullRequest.bodyText:
Abstract
Global Loot Modifiers provide an efficient way to react to loot drops and modify the generated loot without altering loot tables, which proves to be incompatible with other mods as only the "top-most" one wins. Some loot tables, though, cannot be reliably identified via GLMs due to context not being available. One such example is dungeon loot tables, as in there is no way to reliably recognize whether a given loot table represents a dungeon OR which type of dungeon it is. This PR aims to make this possible.
The Solution
NOTE: After the feedback, the "Alternative" solution has been adopted. The old solution description has been kept here for history.
The approached solution consists in assigning an identifier to every loot table, namely the RL that identifies its location inside a datapack. This is a good choice because two loot tables cannot coexist within the same location, otherwise the second would override the first. The given identifier is then passed over to ForgeHooks, which injects it into the loot context prior to passing the loot to the Global Loot Modifier system.
The loot table ID can be queried directly through the context via the getter or via the new forge:loot_table_id LootCondition.
Backwards compatibility and null-safety has been kept by adding a "bouncing" method in ForgeHooks that uses a custom ResourceLocation (forge:unknown) to identify loot tables without an ID. Moreover, the same identifier is returned by LootContext instead of a null value, allowing mods not to null-check for the extremely rare case of a loot table not having an associated ID.
 Old solution
The approached solution consists in assigning an identifier to every loot table, namely the RL that identifies its location inside a datapack. This is a good choice because two loot tables cannot coexist within the same location, otherwise the second would override the first. The given identifier is then passed on to the hook that generates the loot and from there as a parameter to the Global Loot Modifier.
Backwards-compatibility is preserved on the side of Global Loot Modifiers by having the method with the added resource location redirect by default to the original method. The same applies to the default implementation (LootModifier). The old method has also been scheduled for removal in 1.17.
As an example of backwards-compatibility being preserved, one of the examples GLMs has not been updated to use the new method. A new GLM is also provided that illustrates the usage of the new parameter.

nodes.bodyText: I would make this name a bit more unique perhaps, like forge:unknown or something
braces { should be on new line for a forge class
Not sure if this should be patched in? Probably better in ForgeMod or something no?

Expose ILootCondition registration and remove LCM patch

The loot condition type gets statically initialized only when
registering it, which in turn means it should work properly just fine in
regards to registration order.

Signed-off-by: TheSilkMiner <thesilkminer@outlook.com>

commit.message:
Expose ILootCondition registration and remove LCM patch

The loot condition type gets statically initialized only when
registering it, which in turn means it should work properly just fine in
regards to registration order.

Signed-off-by: TheSilkMiner <thesilkminer@outlook.com>
